comments.author: Kris B
comments.content:
When freezing the fruit or cucumber, do you prep it first? Or freeze in large sections, remove moisture, and then slice, etc?

Thanks for this; it's beautiful and informative!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Great question, Kris! I've done it both ways, and it doesn't seem to make a huge difference. I would at least peel it first. I think I slightly prefer just making neat blocks first, then after defrost, "wring" 'em out and slice.

comments.author: amee
comments.content:
Where can I buy Shiso leaves?  Can I buy them at an Asian grocery store?  We have an H mart in Dallas which is the only Asian grocery store I know of...
Thanks for sharing - i really like your blog!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Yes, H Mart will definitely have them, as does Uwajimaya, and many good Asian markets that handle a lot of fresh produce.

comments.author: John
comments.content:
You can also grow Shiso yourself. Around here (New England) it grows like a weed in summer (in fact, it sort of IS a weed .. one plant soon becomes 20; I recommend planting it in pots, and chopping it down before it goes to seed.)

Michael's right, though -- it's a neat flavor.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Good to know it is easy to grow! It is a delicious flavor, it would be fun to always have ready access to it without a trip to the store.

comments.author: Annie
comments.content: Wow this is such a interesting post. I loved reading it and would love to see more like this.

comments.author: Peter
comments.content:
Shiso reseeds itself, so it essentially performs like a perennial.

I use my foodsaver to vacuum-seal anything I want to compress. It's a lot cheaper than the commercial chamber models, and is great for freezing the harvest and sous-vide as well.

comments.author: Evan
comments.content: Wow, looks amazing. I also love the leaf under the glass - picturesque!
